descendants.content:
@Snowshadow @GottaLaff @tarmoamer Haha, I'm Scottish, but have lived in Jasper for one and a half years, and will be returning for the upcoming winter. I left all my winter gear plus the stuff I couldn't get one plane back to Scotland in Jasper.

Look, here's a photo I took from Old Fort Point. Go on, reverse image search it. You won't find it.

Edit: You also seen to claim that my lack of followers and posts means I'm lying, which is a pretty telling comment.

media_attachments.description: Photo of Jasper, AB form Old Fort Point. There is a silt filled river in front of the town and a mountain range behind.

descendants.content:
@sorlud

I truly do not care where you live.
To say "it's funny" losing everything in the #Jasper wildfire is ignorant, and shows a complete lack of empathy for the citizens of that area plus all other Canadians who have lost their businesses, homes, pets, livestock and personal possession due to wildfires.
You say you are returning from Scotland for the winter, with your attitude I hope you never return!
I know you won't be welcomed by anyone who has seen your heartless replies.

@GottaLaff

descendants.content:

descendants.content:
@PandaChronicle @GottaLaff
I am so very sorry you had that experience.
Someone very close to me was a firefighter so I understand your trauma.
When I was a child, my father's place of business was completely destroyed in a fire. (back in those days in small towns and out in the country fire fighting equipment and personnel was not like today). I remember watching it and my parents tears.
I am terrified of fire.

account.note:
Canadian, eh

descendants.content:
@Snowshadow
Rightly so (terror of fire).
With almost 3 decades of hindsight, it pushed me in some good directions, though I don’t recommend it as a motivational experience. It was not nearly as traumatic as having your whole community destroyed by fire. I am very careful now, have a hard time with candles & fireworks.
I got masses of help & support in the months after the fire. Having my community come out to help made it a far less terrible experience than it might have been.

descendants.content:
@PandaChronicle
I am so happy to hear your community helped, that certainly makes the healing process a bit faster. The PTSD never completely goes away though.

I am careful with everything, candles, paper, books, drapes, all my "extension cords" are metal with circuit breakers (powerbars), kitchen fire safety is most important because that is where most home fires begin.

descendants.content:
@PandaChronicle
Yes, it's always wise to remain in the kitchen when anything is cooking, even toast. Also, keeping loose clothing/aprons tied up so it doesn't come near the stove, and same with dish towels, paper towels, etc...
And it's important to keep a pot lid close at hand when using oil for frying to smother any fire.
A large box of baking soda works to extinquish grease fires as well, but never use any flour because it will explode.

yup ask a fire fighter , that is what they recommend.
also, do you know the proper way to use a fire extinguisher?
Have the appropriate fire extinguisher at hand.
Always aim at the base of the fire and NEVER use Water on a grease fire.

account.note: Art is the lie that tells the truth. Attributed to Picasso but known by all artists “Every blade of grass isn’t required to find the beauty in a meadow”  I take forever & a day to vet ,keep my follow list small so we can get to know each other  & visit everyone that follows to find connections & humor but still may not follow back.  I’d rather have strong connections & lots of kind acquaintances than just a giant pool of strangers  & I swear like a longshoreman & block asshats #fedi22

descendants.content: @Snowshadow I lived in houston. The trick is to spray inside all the rubber seals with a thieves blend mixture in a mister. (To remove the smell leave a large stack of damp newspapers in the fridge a couple of days after spraying.) Mist the attic & basement & all air vents. It will kill not just the surface mold like bleach, but the spores in the wood. You can also mist papers & photos that have slightly molded from the water used to put out the fire or from flooding. #Wildfire #Jasper #Flooding

media_attachments.description:
HOW TO MAKE THIEVES BLEND FOR MISTING 

1. 40 drops clove, bud, essential oil 
2. 35 drops lemon, essential oil 
3. 20 drops cinnamon bark essential oil. 
4. 15 drops eucalyptus essential oil. 
5. 10 drops rosemary essential oil.
(l sub tea tree oil for eucalyptus, don’t always add the cloves, but do always add mint and filtered water (half by volume on the H2O )

I lived in Houston. Knowing how to deal with the aftermath from flooding was essential. You can also save photographs an important papers that already have mold spots on them simply missed them with the thieves friend and let them sit out and dry Fisher in this one side, let it dry then the other side and let it dry.

descendants.content:
@Snowshadow

I'm gonna go out on a limb and say those "experts" are working for or in cahoots with appliance makers/dealers.
(Just buy a new one!)

Hard surfaces are the easiest to clean when done properly.

Also, bleach does not kill mold.

But vinegar does.
It's a natural disinfectant.

The trick with vinegar is that it has to sit on the item for a few minutes for the full disinfecting effect.
The smell does not linger once it dries.

I ditched bleach 40 years ago, and before covid, I hadn't been sick for those 40 years.
